title: git Core Cheats
description: Common git commands for day-to-day work.

sections.title: Setup & Config
sections.description: Set up identity and useful defaults.

items.title: Set your identity
items.example:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
items.description: Configure the author name/email used for new commits.

items.title: List current config
items.example:
git config --list
git config --global --list
git config user.email
items.description: Inspect Git configuration (all scopes or a single key).

items.title: Set default branch name
items.example: git config --global init.defaultBranch main
items.description: Make new repositories use `main` as the initial branch.

items.title: Enable auto setup remote
items.example: git config --global push.autoSetupRemote true
items.description: Automatically set upstream when pushing a new branch (Git 2.37+).

items.title: Ignore file patterns
items.example:
# repo-local
echo ".DS_Store" >> .gitignore

# global (macOS example)
git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.config/git/ignore
items.description: Ignore files in one repo via `.gitignore`, or globally via `core.excludesfile`.

items.title: Working tree status
items.example:
git status
git status --short
git status --porcelain
items.description: Show staged/unstaged changes and untracked files.

items.title: See recent commits
items.example:
git log --oneline --decorate --graph --max-count 20
git log --oneline --decorate --graph --all
items.description: Browse commit history in a compact, visual format.

items.title: Show a commit
items.example:
git show HEAD
git show <sha>
git show <sha> --name-only
items.description: Display a commit, its patch, and optionally affected files.

items.title: View diffs
items.example:
git diff
git diff --staged
git diff main...HEAD
items.description: Compare working tree, index, or branches.

items.title: List branches
items.example:
git branch
git branch -vv
git branch -a
items.description: List local branches (and optionally remotes + upstream tracking).

items.title: See remotes
items.example:
git remote -v
git remote show origin
items.description: List remotes and inspect remote-tracking branches.

items.title: Find where a line came from
items.example:
git blame path/to/file.ext
git blame -L 120,180 path/to/file.ext
items.description: Attribute lines to commits (useful for debugging and archaeology).

items.title: Recover recent HEAD states
items.example:
git reflog
git reflog --date=iso
items.description: Show where `HEAD` and branches pointed recently (great for recovery).

items.title: Stage changes
items.example:
git add .
git add -A
git add path/to/file.ext
items.description: Add changes to the index (staging area).

items.title: Stage interactively
items.example:
git add -p
# (use to split a file into multiple commits)
items.description: Stage hunks selectively instead of staging the whole file.

items.title: Unstage changes
items.example:
git restore --staged path/to/file.ext
git reset HEAD -- path/to/file.ext
items.description: Remove changes from the index while keeping your working tree edits.

items.title: Discard local edits
items.example:
git restore path/to/file.ext
git restore .
items.description: Discard working tree changes (use carefully; edits are lost).

items.title: Commit
items.example:
git commit -m "Add feature"
git commit
# opens editor
items.description: Create a commit from staged changes.

items.title: Fix last commit message
items.example: git commit --amend -m "Better message"
items.description: Update the most recent commit (avoid if already pushed/shared).

items.title: Copy a commit onto branch
items.example:
git cherry-pick <sha>
git cherry-pick <sha1> <sha2>
items.description: Apply commit(s) from elsewhere onto your current branch.

sections.title: Branching
sections.description: Create, switch, and clean up branches.

items.title: Create and switch
items.example:
git switch -c feature/my-branch
# older equivalent
git checkout -b feature/my-branch
items.description: Create a new branch and check it out.

items.title: Switch branches
items.example:
git switch main
git switch -
items.description: Move between branches (`-` toggles to previous branch).

items.title: Rename branch
items.example:
git branch -m old-name new-name
# rename current branch
git branch -m new-name
items.description: Rename a local branch.

items.title: Delete local branch
items.example:
git branch -d feature/my-branch
# force delete (unmerged)
git branch -D feature/my-branch
items.description: Delete a local branch (safe delete refuses if not merged).

items.title: Track a remote branch
items.example:
git fetch origin
git switch --track origin/feature/my-branch
# shorthand if branch name matches
git switch feature/my-branch
items.description: Create a local branch that tracks a remote branch.

items.title: Clone
items.example:
git clone https://github.com/org/repo.git
git clone git@github.com:org/repo.git
items.description: Create a local copy of a remote repository.

items.title: Fetch
items.example:
git fetch
git fetch origin
git fetch --prune
items.description: Download new objects/refs without modifying your current branch.

items.title: Pull
items.example:
git pull
git pull --rebase
git pull origin main
items.description: Fetch and integrate changes into the current branch (merge or rebase).

items.title: Push
items.example:
git push
git push -u origin feature/my-branch
git push --set-upstream origin feature/my-branch
items.description: Upload commits to a remote, optionally setting upstream tracking.

items.title: Delete remote branch
items.example:
git push origin --delete feature/my-branch
# equivalent
git push origin :feature/my-branch
items.description: Remove a branch from the remote.

items.title: Update remote URL
items.example:
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:org/repo.git
git remote -v
items.description: Change the remote URL (e.g., switch HTTPS â†” SSH).

items.title: Merge branch
items.example:
git switch main
git merge feature/my-branch
items.description: Merge another branch into the current branch.

items.title: Rebase onto main
items.example:
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/main
items.description: Replay your branch commits on top of an updated base.

items.title: Continue/abort rebase
items.example:
git rebase --continue
git rebase --abort
git rebase --skip
items.description: Manage an in-progress rebase during conflict resolution.

items.title: Resolve conflicts
items.example:
# after resolving files
git add path/to/file.ext
git commit
# or during rebase
git rebase --continue
items.description: After fixing conflicts, stage resolved files and continue the operation.

items.title: Preview merge base
items.example:
git merge-base main HEAD
git log --oneline $(git merge-base main HEAD)..HEAD
items.description: Find the common ancestor between branches.

items.title: Stash changes
items.example:
git stash
git stash push -m "wip: refactor"
git stash -u  # include untracked
items.description: Save local changes without committing them.

items.title: List and inspect stashes
items.description: See what you stashed and what it contains.

items.title: Apply or pop
items.description: Re-apply stashed changes (pop also removes the stash entry).

items.title: Drop or clear
items.example:
git stash drop stash@{0}
git stash clear
items.description: Remove one stash entry or all stashes.

sections.title: Undo & Recovery
sections.description: Safely back out changes and recover mistakes.

items.title: Revert a commit (safe for shared history)
items.example:
git revert <sha>
git revert HEAD
items.description: Create a new commit that undoes an existing commit.

items.title: Reset branch pointer
items.example:
# keep changes staged
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# keep changes unstaged
git reset --mixed HEAD~1

# discard changes entirely (dangerous)
git reset --hard HEAD~1
items.description: Move `HEAD`/branch to another commit (soft/mixed/hard control what happens to changes).

items.title: Restore a file from another commit
items.example:
git restore --source <sha> path/to/file.ext
# older equivalent
git checkout <sha> -- path/to/file.ext
items.description: Bring back a previous version of a file without switching branches.

items.title: Find lost commit via reflog
items.example:
git reflog
# then recover
git branch recover/<name> <sha>
items.description: Use reflog to locate old commit SHAs and create a recovery branch.

sections.title: Tags
sections.description: Mark releases or important points in history.

items.title: Create an annotated tag
items.example:
git tag -a v1.2.3 -m "v1.2.3"
git tag -a v1.2.3 <sha>
items.description: Create a signed/annotated pointer to a commit (preferred for releases).

items.title: List and show tags
items.example:
git tag
git tag -l "v1.*"
git show v1.2.3
items.description: Browse tags and inspect what they point to.

items.title: Push tags
items.example:
git push origin v1.2.3
git push origin --tags
items.description: Publish tags to the remote.

items.title: Delete a tag
items.example:
# local
git tag -d v1.2.3

# remote
git push origin :refs/tags/v1.2.3
items.description: Remove a tag locally and/or from the remote.

sections.title: Search
sections.description: Locate commits, changes, and text quickly.

items.title: Search text in repo
items.example:
git grep "TODO"
git grep -n "functionName" -- path/to/dir
items.description: Search tracked content (fast, respects `.gitignore`).

items.title: Search commits by message
items.example:
git log --grep="fix" --oneline
git log --grep="JIRA-123" --oneline
items.description: Find commits whose commit message matches a pattern.

items.title: Search commits by patch content
items.example:
git log -S "mySymbol" --oneline
git log -G "regexPattern" --oneline
items.description: Find commits that add/remove a string (`-S`) or match a regex in diffs (`-G`).
